This says it all - a lunatic fringe, to which I'll add heartless, anti-science, anti-intellectual, anti-anything-Obama says, has taken over the party. This party will have to purge these elements if it wants to remain a force in the future.

asset.assetTitle: President Obama and the Long March (28thu1)

taxonomies.name: President Obama and the Long March (28thu1)

comments.commentBody:
To quote another great past President from his first inaugural address: "So, first of all, let me assert my firm belief that the only thing we have to fear is fear itself—nameless, unreasoning, unjustified terror which paralyzes needed efforts to convert retreat into advance."
Most of the fear stoked by Trump and the GOP is nameless, unreasoning and unjustified. In fact the only thing I fear now is that he may end up winning. C'mon my fellow citizens, wake up, and wake up your friends and neighbors. Let us all get up and vote Hillary and give her a thumping resounding victory in November.

asset.assetTitle: The Democrats (Try to) Grow Up (26mag-dnc)

comments.commentBody:
The Democrtas have been their own worst enemy, at least in the recent past. In 1968, the ultra liberal left wing of the party took control and it resulted in Nixon for (almost) two terms. We know more recently what happened when Al Gore spurned Bill Clinton's support and endorsement and handed (well, the SCOTUS actually handed, but that is another story) the office to GWB for eight years.
Let us not repeat mistakes from history. Let us unite and rally behind Hillary Clinton and ensure that the White House will never ever see Donald trump.

newswire.byline: By ARTHUR C. BROOKS and GAIL COLLINS
newswire.title: Unconventional Hardly Covers It
newswire.abstract: Brooks and Collins on Sanders, Trump, Cruz, Clinton, Kaine, friends, Romans and countrymen.

comments.commentBody:
At the beginning Brooks feigns being shocked that Trump had disappointed Collins.
He then went on to note that in his acceptance speech, Trump "avoided creating any media scandals by staying absolutely on script." He furthe rnotes, "Job done" and guessed that the Trump "team was exchanging high fives."
So, this is the standard that satisfies Brooks. Stay on script and the job is done. No need for policy or ideas. Just avoid a scandal.
So let me close by asking Brooks the following question: Does Trump satisfy you and meet your expectations? If so, say so. If not, say so. It is time to take a stand and stop waffling.

comments.commentBody:
As Rosenthal points out the only thing Trump is consistent about is that he never backs down and in fact doubles down.
This is very much like a 2-year old whose only world view is the one that ends at the tip of his nose and whose only objective function is to advance personal well-being.
Most kids grow out of these tendencies and develop into well adjusted men and women. But not Trump.
And he has 13 million people in his corner! That is the scarier part of his ascendancy.

That Trump has any knowledge of anything is news to me. He is not unlike a 2-year old whose world focus is limited to his own welfare.
What is even more scary is that a large number of the Republicans have decided to make him their standard bearer.
I hope enough Americans saw the week-long coronation of The Donald in Cleveland although Woodstock would have been a better setting. There was more order and certainly more love in Woodstock.

Eric Thayer for The New York Times

newswire.abstract: Who said it couldn’t happen here? Rising to the top of the Republican ticket, Trump has activated forces on the political right that cannot be deactivated.

comments.commentBody:
Two aspects of Trump's ascendancy stand out. And they are both scary, very scary.
First, as Daniel Rogers (professor emeritus of history at Princeton) notes, Trumps has an authoritarian style. He brooks no opposition and starts with calling his opponents names, in grade school style, before rising to the level of asking his supporters to physically attack them. After all he has been endorsed by none other than Valdimir Putin, the ultimate strongman. People who hold authoritarian views make up the bulk of his supporters.
Second, the largest segment (estimated at 89.7%) of Trump's supporters are white folk who hold negative views of blacks. In other words, there is more than a hint of racism present in this segment. And the fact that there are 13 million Americans, as evidenced by their vote for him in the primaries, who share this view is scary.
His authoritarian style and racist appeals make Trump's ascendancy atop the GOP very scary. We do need to make America safe again (to borrow the headline from the convention), safe from the likes of Trump becoming POTUS. And that is in your hands America.

Be warned that words can turn into action. And then we would not be like Gambia, we'd be a lot worse.

newswire.abstract: Well, not exactly. But Cruz’s appearance at the G.O.P. convention shows how self-interest routinely muscles principle aside.

comments.commentBody:
For all the jokes about Lindsay Graham that have been written in these pages, he has publicly disavowed Trump and distanced himself from his party's nominee.
Even though I have disagreed with many of George Will's writings, I applaud his courage in leaving the party and saying so publicly.
But the vast majority that includes the likes of Chris Christie, Mike Pence, Marco Rubio, Ben Carson, Rick Perry, John McCain, Paul Ryan and others, have decided to put their tails between their legs and throw their support for The Donald.
The one man who leads this list is Ted Cruz. He has suggested that the media helped The Donald win because they are liberal and wanted to feed Hillary Clinton the most easily beatable opponent.
This is not a political party that has any focus or interest in America and Americans. Each one is in it for his or her own self and is looking forward to the next election cycle, be it 2018 or 2020.
I hope enough Americans are watching this unseemly drama. I hope enough Americans will go to the polls in November and send a resounding lesson to these hucksters and charlatans.

newswire.abstract: The struggle for the nomination is over, but the struggle for the soul of the party is not.

comments.commentBody:
This is a feeble attempt at speaking half-truths and offering half-apologies. For instance, he lists past Presidents Ronald Reagan, George H. W. Bush and George W. Bush and Republican nominees Bob Dole, John McCain and Mitt Romney, and states that their appeal to the American public was not based on "racism, nativism, and misogyny."

In the very next sentence, he goes on to note that "there existed in the Republican Party repulsive elements, people who were attracted to racial and ethnic politics and moved by resentment and intolerance rather than a vision of the good."

It is to these elements that the past Presidents and nominees pitched their appeals, often in coded language. Whenever Reagan spoke of states rights he could be interpreted as saying that the southern states had a right to determine their policies on slavery, gun control, abortion, birth control, gay rights, rather than giving in to a federal law. When Romney spoke of the "47% who pay no income taxes" he was appealing to the rich Republicans.

So, there are no more than half-truths and half-apologies in Wehner's analysis. Only when he and others in his party openly disavow these people and their beliefs without using coded language will the Republicans find their way back to Lincoln.

newswire.abstract: No matter what you think of his time in office, it’s hard to argue that the human being has been anything less than a model of class and dignity.

Obama the President will be judged by future historians as one of the great Presidents. After all he did save the American and global economy, reverse the bleeding losses in jobs, get Obamacare passed, not start a war and tried his best to close down currents wars and Guantanamo.
But what is clearly evident is that Obama the man, the husband, and the father is a shining model. We do not need the future to tell us what is palpably obvious right now, right here.

newswire.abstract: White male college graduates play a bigger role in his nationalist movement than is commonly understood.

comments.commentBody:
When the college educated is not split by gender, Clinton leads by six points. But when gender is taken into account, Clinton loses males in a plurality.
But this still does not clearly identify the role of college education. As Rosenthal points out, there has been an expansion in the lower tier college education over the past fifty years. He notes that there are "relatively more students graduating from Cal State Hayward or Cal State Dominguez Hills than from Berkeley or UCLA." This is not bad, but if the college educated males were to be split along the lines of the type of college they graduated from, I suspect there will be a significant difference.
This is mainly because a basic college education from any college or university has pretty much become the default just like a high school diploma was fifty years back.

A partly burned flag before a 2015 demonstration on the anniversary of a fatal police shooting in Ferguson, Mo.

newswire.abstract: Europe in the 1930s and America in the 1890s faced many troubling conditions like we do today. They responded with very different answers.

comments.commentBody:
Brooks is right in that some see "their sense of self-worth on their tribe, not their behavior." This leads to resentment that spirals downward and "deeper into the addiction of their own victimology." Any politician who spins this situation as the result of any other entity - be it immigrants or muslims - will develop a cadre of followers.

But Brooks also overlooks another facilitator - the GOp and right wing media headed by FOX news. They stoke and spread these falsities and convert a brush fire into a raging inferno. And now everything and everyone is unmoored from fats and reality. Up becomes down, down becomes up.

The complete story involves all the factors Brooks touches upon AND an active encouraging push from the GOP and FOX news. Unless you clearly identify these two agencies and their role the picture is not complete.

comments.commentBody:
"Gail, I’m sorry to have to open with the obvious point that it was a terrible week. More African-Americans shot and killed by law enforcement, followed by the mass murder of police officers in Dallas."

When Arthur Brooks opens with an apology (even a feigned one) and acknowledges a fact (that more African-Americans were shot and killed by law enforcement), it suggests that even hardened right-wingers are finally opening their eyes to the reality on the ground. Maybe he will be able to persuade other right wingers that regulating the purchase and use of guns and banning assault rifles is not exactly violating the second amendment. Or maybe I am being too generous and optimistic.

It is time to throw out the bums! Are you up to it America?

newswire.abstract: Security delays are only the most visible sign of the budgetary con game that is hobbling the federal government

comments.commentBody:
Mr. Rattner asks us to think as we are waiting in line at the airport security check point. He writes, "Something to think about while you’re waiting in line."

I think the time to "think while waiting in line" is over. It is time to throw out the Republican candidates lock, stock, and barrel - at every level of government. We need an overhaul of the people who we elect to run our governments - at all levels, starting with the most local city and town governments.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/The Power of Altruism (08brooks)
asset.assetTitle: The Power of Altruism (08brooks)

newswire.title: The Power of Altruism
newswire.abstract: We inherently desire to do good, but society’s assumptions of selfishness affect our behavior.

comments.commentBody:
Brooks notes that the roots of modern capitalistic thinking lay in Adam Smith's pioneering work "An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations" in 1776. He then notes that, "Since then, the institutions that arouse the moral lens have withered while the institutions that manipulate incentives — the market and the state — have expanded."

It was not in 1776 that the withering of moral institutions began. It began in 1980 under St. Reagan. He began the trend to privatize anything and everything that could be. Privatize jails, privatize local security, why he and subsequently GWB even tried to privatize social security.

All in the name of the efficiency of markets. Markets are efficient, but not everything needs to be in the market sector. For a more detailed analysis please read Michael Sandel's book "What Money Can't Buy." Here is a link to his talk:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GvDpYHyBlgc

taxonomies.name: The G.O.P. Waits, and Waits, for Donald Trump to Grow Up (29wallace)

comments.commentBody:
If anyone knows how hard it is to teach the unteachable it is Nicolle Wallace. She had the unenviable task of teaching Sarah Palin, the one who knows by peering into a pair of binoculars.
And when she opines that the Donald will never ever learn, we ought to listen. The Donald is interested in listening to two things: his own voice and a thunderous applause when he pauses for breath before spouting the next sentence. He is uninterested in governing.
I can only hope that more GOPers will publicly rebuke the Donald. I hope enough Americans are seeing how Brexiters are backpedaling from all the promises they made. And seeing all this, I hope that enough Americans have the sense to not vote for him in the general election.

taxonomies.name: You Break It, You Own It (29friedman)

comments.commentBody:
"Attention Donald Trump voters: this is what happens to a country that falls for hucksters who think that life can just imitate Twitter — that there are simple answers to hard questions — and that small men can rearrange big complex systems by just erecting a wall and everything will be peachy.

But I digress."

No you do not digress at all. When politicians (or for that matter anyone) offers solutions that can be uttered in less that 140 words, a red flag should go up. Instead we have people flocking to those who claim to be able to solve problems at the snap of a finger. Thankfully Americans still have time to rethink their lover affair with the Donald.

taxonomies.name: Britain to Leave Europe for a Lie (28iht-edcohen28)

comments.commentBody:
Many of those in favor of Brexit are backpedaling, real fast and real hard. The simple fact is that they did not expect to win, they only wanted to rattle the cages. And now that they have won, they have no idea what to do. They cannot deliver on the promised economic boom or curtailed immigration. Their lies have been exposed, simple as that.
This, I hope, provides a valuable lesson to Americans who are in awe of those who promise to build a wall and get Mexico to pay for it, or ban all Muslims as a way of curbing terrorism, or rescinding Obamacare on the first day of office. Beware, none of these is possible. Don't learn that lesson after helping this side win the election.

taxonomies.name: Britain Leaves on a Cry of Anger and Frustration (25sat1)

comments.commentBody:
The two sides have been presenting two different arguments. The "stay" folks focus on economics whereas the "exit" folks focus on migration. The two may be tenuously connected in that people migrate to improve their economic situation, but for those who are not mobile there is no upside to migration since their economic status remains frozen, or in fact may deteriorate.
It is a serious conundrum with no easy answer. One solution is for government to invest more in their citizens and infrastructure; something that has been stymied by opposition from conservatives.
Hopefully enough Americans see this and come to their senses in November.

comments.commentBody:
Being "at the edge of inside" is a clever way to describe a person who believes in the system enough to help correct it so that it works even better rather than demolish the system completely as a rank outsider might.
I wonder if he Brooks realizes how much of his writing has trended in that direction. He was deeply entrenched in the GOP establishment and has been looking for an exit in the recent past. I wonder if the establishment sees his critique and begins the process of correcting itself. If not I urge him to take a couple more steps and go to the "edge of outside" from where he can better serve the people of America rather than the GOP establishment.

comments.commentBody:
Cohen notes that Brexit is a "revolt against global capitalism." Maybe so. But it is clearly a vote against integration and people migration. And a vote for nationalism.
These are the very same forces in play here in the USA. Trump represents rabid nationalism. And now I fear that he will have enough support to win the election in November.
I hope enough Americans are watching this and come out and vote Hillary Clinton into office. We'll need her stable hand so that America can be the stabilizing force for the next few rocky years.

taxonomies.name: Is There Any Dignity Left in Politics? (21conversation)

comments.commentBody:
As always Arthur Brooks likes to drop some names, the honorable Dalai Lama was the one he used this time. No matter my priors on Brooks, I commend him for this collaboration and would urge him to write more about it in future columns.

But the real bombshell, or not, was Brooks admitting that there were no policy proposals from the Trump camp. He said that Collins's question was a "trick question." And all she asked for was for him to "name one policy on which you think Donald Trump has the better take."

I don't know what Trump's supporters see in him. God help us if ever he got near, leave alone inside, the White House.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Has Political Fear-Mongering Lost Its Appeal? (19tomasky)
asset.assetTitle: Has Political Fear-Mongering Lost Its Appeal? (19tomasky)

taxonomies.name: Has Political Fear-Mongering Lost Its Appeal? (19tomasky)

comments.commentBody:
Tomasky continues to make the same mistake once again. He starts off being a little contrite and introspective and wonders if the pundits (a category in which he places himself, which in of itself supposedly shows humility even as he is bragging about his status as a knowledgeable pundit) really understands the collective minds of the American public. He notes that fear mongering was believed to be a true and tried technique to appeal to the American public. With a great deal of certitude he writes, "This we know."

But then along comes the massacre in Orlando. And the Donald tries to stoke fear, the definitive way to increase his appeal, as "we know." But his poll numbers tanked. And immediately Tomasky formulates another theory of how the American voter's mind works. One event, one poll. Enough to construct yet another theory.

Maybe Tomasky is right. In fact there is a part of me that is rooting that he be right. But he is wrong in so quickly coming to this conclusion. Punditry is more than following one poll. Just ask Nate Silver!

newswire.abstract: To some, a classified section of an inquiry into the terrorist attacks points to Saudi involvement, while the country’s foreign minister says, “There is no there there.”

comments.commentBody:
“There is no there there,” he said.

I beg to differ.
There is a lot of evidence of the Saudis spreading the hard line Wahabi tenets throughout the world.
There is a lot of evidence that the Saudis hated Saddam Hussein, who besides having invaded Kuwait, was also seen as too secular and hence an apostate.
There is lot of evidence that the mullahs and imams in Saudi Arabia did not fully approve of American military presence in the holy land.

Taken collectively these suggest that the Saudis would be thrilled to see the WTC towers come crashing down.

Sometimes you don't need direct evidence of culpability; there is strong evidence otherwise.

asset.assetTitle: A Party Agrift (13krugman)

comments.commentBody:
"Were they just incompetent, or is there something structural about the modern Republican Party that makes it unable to confront grifters?"

The answer is clear. It all began on a sunny day when St. Reagan spoke of the evils of government even as he was trying to get elected as executive in the very government he was denouncing. It is very much like a con artist telling people to invest in a company that s/he himself was shorting. That con has gone on for nearly 40 years. And now we see in its pinnacle the ultimate con man.

The question as to whether it was incompetence or a structural problem is a false pair. There is one answer.

taxonomies.name: As Rich Nations Turn Their Backs (29sun1)

des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
newswire.title: As Rich Nations Turn Their Backs
newswire.abstract: World leaders seem more interested in barricading their nations from the fallout of conflict than in dealing with its root causes.

comments.commentBody:
Once again Angela Merkel stands out in the panoply of leaders of the world's rich countries. Kudos to her.

Having said that, pouring more money into humanitarian aid cannot be a permanent solution to the problems of those who are under-serviced or dislocated. If you peel another layer of this proverbial onion, it is clear that many strongmen and dictators cow-tow to the rich countries that buy their allegiance with aid, typically in the form of military equipment that is too often used to suppress their own people.

The case of Saudi Arabia is a classic example. I want your oil but, in return, will you please keep a lid on your citizen's desire for civil rights? Here are some tanks, missiles and guns. Thank you very much. There are far too many other such countries to note here.

We need to stop this nefarious links. The, and then only, will we have made real progress in stemming the humanitarian crises.

comments.commentBody: Thank you Mr. Weston for sharing your very personal story in such a moving manner on such a memorable day. I applaud your visiting each and every one of the 32 graveyard sites. But, as you note, the matter of people dying in a war is age-old and unlikely to abate anytime soon. With the move to an all volunteer army less and less people are directly connected to a nation's war effort. Others have noted that it is the 1% who are enrolled in the army and the civilians close to the battle field that feel the direct negative effects (so disingenuously referred to by the more bland term 'collateral damage') of war.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/The Liberal Blind Spot (29kristof)
asset.assetTitle: The Liberal Blind Spot (29kristof)

newswire.title: The Liberal Blind Spot
newswire.abstract: When I called for my fellow progressives to welcome conservative academics on campus, readers were in agreement that I was dead wrong.

comments.commentBody:
First, Kristof notes that “more than half of academics in some fields would discriminate against a job seeker who they learned was an evangelical.” He brands this a form of bigotry, but that is not where the matter stops. The evangelical begins to nudge the scriptures and fights the university’s health care policy because it includes contraception. At that stage it is no longer bigotry to resist an evangelical.

Second, Kristof laments the lack of diversity and notes that only one professor in 10 in the humanities or social sciences is a Republican.” Today’s Republican party has become anti-intellectual. And that is in direct conflict with any university’s mission, i.e., plant and nurture seeds of intellectual curiosity. It seems only natural to avoid an anti-intellectual party.

Third, Kristof warns that when academics cluster at one end of the political spectrum, they will marginalize themselves. In sociology and anthropology, at the very least one would expect researchers to have respect for their human subjects. If you look at the rhetoric of many Republicans, it is clear that they have very little respect for human life unless it is an embryo or a yet-to-born fetus.

I applaud Kristof’s effort to have a balanced analysis of the academic community but absent very fundamental changes in the right’s views and attitudes, academics will continue to cluster at the left end of the political spectrum.

comments.commentBody:
“Nobody wants to be in the bottom half,” Mr. Daly said. “So over time, the average compensation in any group goes up.”

I am reminded of Garrison Keillor's closing statement:
"Well, that's the news from Lake Wobegon, where all the women are strong, all the men are good looking, and all the children are above average."

If everyone wants to be above average, the only solution is to keep moving the relevant metrics - be it strength or beauty or wealth - higher and higher. This is an explosive situation that has no self-correcting push back. And that is why we need regulations to reign them in.

comments.commentBody:
Abbott claims that climate change is bunk because it had been “happening since the earth’s beginning.”

Oh well, but at that time there were no humans and so their survival was not an issue. A few molten rocks zipping around was not a problem. But since I am around now and hope that my kids and their kids will be around for a while, deforestation, rising ocean levels, extreme winters and summers, tornadoes, and other such disasters are not so welcome any more.

Abbot may not care much about his children and grand children and their children, but I, along with most of the rest of us, do care.

comments.commentBody:
Mr. Thomas, now business editor at The San Francisco Chronicle notes that Mr. Thiel "did discuss his sexuality, but it was known to a wide circle who felt that it was not fit for discussion beyond that circle. I thought that attitude was retrograde and homophobic, and that informed my reporting. I believe that he was out and not in the closet.”

I see no particular value is spreading the word about one's sexual orientation or preferences unless it includes child molestation, rape and other offensive behaviors. Who cares if Mr. Thiel was straight or gay. This line of argument does not hold water.

On the other hand, reading that Mr. Thiel is a pledged delegate for The Donald made me cringe. But here again, who am I to judge Mr. Thiel's choices in Presidential candidates. It is not a crime to support The Donald, except it is surprising in my opinion.

newswire.abstract: A new kind of centralized media, and a new kind of power.

comments.commentBody:
Douthat notes that ". . . Facebook’s list of “trending topics” is curated by a group of toiling journalists, not just an impersonal algorithm, . . . . "

It may come as a surprise to Douthat that there is no impersonal algorithm. All algorithms are written by programmers, who are people. Just people who like to use past behaviors of the FB user to figure out what is the best collection of information/topics to feed back to that user. If there is any source for the supposed bias, it is in that people are seeking more left-leaning information and the programmers are merely supplying them what they want.

For a more thorough discussion read:
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/19/opinion/the-real-bias-built-in-at-face...

newswire.title: How Facebook Warps Our Worlds
newswire.abstract: It’s not about algorithms and invisible sorcery. It’s about instincts much older than that.

comments.commentBody:
That people have a confirmation bias is a well known phenomenon in psychology. In other words we seek information that confirm our naive theories. And that too from people who think and act like ourselves. This bias gets exaggerated in the context of social issues that do not have clear-cut answer or in cases of emotionally charged issues.

What FB has done is to speed the process; it has not changed the fundamental process.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confirmation_bias

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Tricky Timing for the Class of 2016 (15sun1)
asset.assetTitle: Tricky Timing for the Class of 2016 (15sun1)

taxonomies.name: Tricky Timing for the Class of 2016 (15sun1)

newswire.title: Tricky Timing for the Class of 2016
newswire.abstract: Employment prospects for today’s graduates are far from ideal.

comments.commentBody:
It is true that this year's graduating class is entering a tough and uncertain economy.

But here is a question I have for these graduating students: Do you promise to be involved and actively participate in local matters?

Why do I ask what I believe to be an important question? Simply because politics is not like a reality show and only active participation by the younger folks (who are known to be very fickle and have a low turnout at the polls) can blunt the dangerous trend of making campaigning a reality TV show. If only enough of the younger folks had voted in the 2010 election we would not have had the emergence of the Tea Party whose effects are being felt even during this year's Presidential campaign.

Get out an vote, not just during the Presidential election but in the off years. And also remain engaged in the local politics at the city and state levels.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Is There Too Much Democracy in America or Too Little? (15lind)
asset.assetTitle: Is There Too Much Democracy in America or Too Little? (15lind)

taxonomies.name: Is There Too Much Democracy in America or Too Little? (15lind)

comments.commentBody:
The question is not whether there is too much democracy in America or too little?

Here are a few better questions:
1. Is there too much money in American politics or too little?
2. Are there too many uneducated/undereducated American citizens or too few?
3. Is the time for campaigning in America too much or too little?
4. Is the media in America paying too much attention to trivial banalities or too little?

These and others like these are at the root of what is happening in this election cycle.

taxonomies.name: Donald Trump and Paul Ryan Meet, With a Chasm Between Them (13repubs)

comments.commentBody:
This meeting of Paul Ryan and Donald Trump is described as a "custody negotiation between estranged parents, with the Republican Party caught in the middle."

Later it is noted that "the political incentives are all heavily in favor of conciliation."

This analogy is erroneous. In a custody battle between estranged parents, generally both sides tend to share a common concern for the children caught in the middle of this battle. However, the political incentives only favor reconciliation because it is good for the two sides.

BUT IT IS NOT GOOD FOR THE AMERICAN PEOPLE. So, this is more like a custody battle between parents neither one of whom is interested in the welfare of their children but only in the share of the loot they'll get after the breakup.

multimedia.caption: President Obama last week. A visit to Hiroshima was hotly debated within the White House for months as Mr. Obama planned his trip to Vietnam and Japan.
President Obama last week. A visit to Hiroshima was hotly debated within the White House for months as Mr. Obama planned his trip to Vietnam and Japan.
President Obama last week. A visit to Hiroshima was hotly debated within the White House for months as Mr. Obama planned his trip to Vietnam and Japan.
President Obama last week. A visit to Hiroshima was hotly debated within the White House for months as Mr. Obama planned his trip to Vietnam and Japan.

newswire.abstract: The visit carries weighty symbolism for the president, who does not want to be seen as apologizing for America’s use of atomic bombs to help end World War II.

comments.commentBody:
Obama's critics have accused him of undertaking an "apology tour" in the first year of his Presidency. Only those who see no error ever, or at the very least, acknowledge any error ever, would have called it an "apology tour."

I can see President Trump visiting the Korean peninsula after ordering a nuclear strike and gloating about it. I can see President trump build a "yuge beaootiful" wall along the southern border and have a public ceremony toasting its construction.

And how can we forget GWB and his "Mission Accomplished" picture in a bomber jacket. For a guy who took the easy way out of Vietnam it was a very tasteless choice of attire, leaving alone the fact that nothing had been accomplished.

Somehow these pictures, as grating as they are, are seen as projecting American power. But a President giving a nuanced analysis of nuclear weapons is seen as weakness. Those who wish to anoint America the greatest country don't seem to understand that such recognition has to be accorded by others and is never given by oneself.

asset.taxonomy: sunday-review/Giving a Name, and Dignity, to a Disability (08barry)
asset.assetTitle: Giving a Name, and Dignity, to a Disability (08barry)

taxonomies.name: Giving a Name, and Dignity, to a Disability (08barry)

comments.commentBody:
Meanings of words change as we march forward. Take for instance the term housewife. About a century ago this was the preferred that term that referred to a married woman who typically took care of her family and stayed at home. This was replaced by the term homemaker with the intention of giving more respectability to the job of managing a family home. This too has been displaced by the term "stay-at-home" prefix to a mother or father.

Famously Juliet says "What's in a name? that which we call a rose
By any other name would smell as sweet." But in the real world in which we live, we do not merely identify an object by using a term, we also imply many other characteristics. And as society evolves, these meanings and attributions change. And that is why meanings of words keep evolving.

Today it could be "intellectually disabled" or a "person with intellectual disability," tomorrow it will surely be something else.

asset.assetTitle: Sex and the Singular Pol (08bruni)

newswire.title: Sex and the Singular Pol
newswire.abstract: Donald Trump is the first modern-day nominee to own up to his erotic escapades, but it’s not progress.

comments.commentBody:
I have to slightly disagree with Bruni. Granted that JFK and Bill Clinton had their flings, but times were different. I am not saying what they did was right but just that they were a lot more muted about their conquests. This did not make it right, but they did not advertise their conquests. In fact, many used to argue that their flings were not the country's problem.

So what makes the Donald's philandering different. Times are different; these are the days when news travels faster than the speed of light.. And if anything people are more understanding and accommodating nowadays. Nonetheless, there is more than a whiff of crassness in the way the Donald speaks about his sexploits and women, even his own wife and daughters. He looked at Tiffany, his daughter, when she was a few weeks old baby and gushed at the prospect of her developing voluptuous breasts. He has publicly stated that he'd date his daughter Ivana if only she were not his daughter. He has spoken about avoiding STDs just like avoiding being drafted to Vietnam.

So even though times are different and social mores in regards sex have evolved since the days of JFK, the Donald makes it crass. And that is a unique skill he has like no one else.

newswire.abstract: Clinton vs. Trump could be the ugliest presidential contest of modern times. But in that mess there may still be an opportunity for constructive dialogue.

comments.commentBody:
So far its clear that a lot of Americans feel they have been left out of the economic system as seen by the strong backing for Trump and Sanders. The question for Clinton is whether she can address their concerns without stooping to the level of hurling personal insults or talking in vague generalities.

It is not just all of America but all of the world that will be watching this debate. And as long as she stays on point and does not take Trump's bait for hurling vicious personal insults, she'll do fine.

But then again, stranger things have happened. Like the GOP nominating Trump! Fasten your seat belts; you're in for a bumpy ride.

He not only stares - lovingly or scarily, you be the judge - from behind the podium, but he also brings his wife along for added value. And on top of all that he's ready to chauffeur Mr. Trump.

newswire.abstract: What do we give up when we micromanage our vacations?

comments.commentBody:
“You have to make sure you get the best one.”

Therein lies the problem - maximizing. If best is the option that you seek, chances that you'll end up disappointed rather than satisfied are far greater. Look at the issue thus: If you want the sharpest needle in the proverbial haystack, you'll have to search the entire haystack and the size of the haystack determines the search effort, whereas if you are looking for a needle that will help you stitch, the search effort becomes independent of the size of the haystack.

This is not to say that searching is bad or worthless, just that excessive searching and looking for the "best" option can be needlessly stressful and wasteful.

newswire.abstract: Prince appears to have had a problem with pain pills, one that grew so acute that his friends turned to an addiction doctor just before his death.

comments.commentBody:
People, especially fans, expect superhuman capabilities from the stars they follow and adore. Stars, on their part, usually thrive on such adoration, which itself becomes a drug of sorts. In this complex milieu if one were to throw in a drug dependency, it becomes a toxic environment that results in a downward spiral.

It is too early to say if Prince suffered through the process outlined above and maybe there are other reasons why he met with his untimely end. He was a major force in the world of music. Maybe the tragic end might have been averted had he reached out for help earlier on.

In any case RIP musical genius.

A campaign rally in Bridgeport, Conn. Blue-state Republicans helped put Donald Trump over the top.

newswire.abstract: Was the Trump phenomenon impossible to foresee, or did we miss important clues along the way? A look back at a strange primary season.

comments.commentBody:
This is an extensive and thorough analysis of why most pundits (not just Nate Cohn) underestimated Trump's chances.

Among all the reasons one that stands out, at least in my mind, is the shrinking middle class and the growing income/wealth divide in our country right now. There was a time, just after WWII or so, when many Americans started to move up in life with an economic expansion resulting from technological innovations and a robust manufacturing economy. All of that slowed down as the world morphed into one giant community with the elimination of the First, Second and Third worlds and the onset of globalization. These past 25+ years have been hard on the lower and uneducated class of Americans who saw jobs leaving our country even as people in China and India saw an economic expansion.

Most would agree with my review thus far, although disagreements may begin now onward. American in the lower and uneducated class tended to support the Republican party although the party's policies post Reagan were never really in this group's favor. And now Donald Trump has exposed that yawning gap resulting in his massive support. Most of the racist and xenophobic tendencies only reflect a deeper economic malaise.

Whoever is the next President will have to invest in our country's science & technology and infrastructure - these seem the most obvious ways to reinvigorate our economy.

newswire.abstract: Fewer T.S.A. screeners, tighter budgets, new checkpoint procedures and growing numbers of passengers have led to epic security lines, and there’s no end in sight.

comments.commentBody:
Budget cuts are certainly a problem and we should blame the Republicans for that.

But should we also not blame the kabuki theater we have at airports? One man failed to bring down a plane with a bomb in his shoe and ever since hundreds of millions of people have had to take off their shoes at the security theater. Another man failed to bring down a plane with a bomb in his underwear, but thankfully we don't have to strip down to our underwear.

And for this theater we can once again blame GWB and his Republican colleagues who are still waging a "war on terror."

All the while our bridges crumble, our roads have potholes, and our teachers are underpaid.

newswire.abstract: Born-again Christian. Public servant. Child molester. He’s a study in the messiness of human nature.

comments.commentBody:
The thing that bothers me is that having extra marital affairs, while not a desirable idea, is pilloried by the likes of Dennis Hastert even as they abuse young children.

Catholic priests are another example of those who denounce, in public, certain behaviors that they themselves engage in.

Take Larry Craig, another GOP Senator with a self-righteous strain. He was angling for gay sex in a bathroom in an airport even as he lambasted gays in general.

I don't know how these folks compartmentalize their strong vitriolic views and their own behaviors. There must be some special talent for spewing venom against gays, lesbians, adulterers, child molesters while engaging in the very same behaviors.

asset.taxonomy: blogs/well/Do Children in France Have a Healthier Relationship With Alcohol? (20160428)
asset.assetTitle: Do Children in France Have a Healthier Relationship With Alcohol? (20160428)

taxonomies.name: Do Children in France Have a Healthier Relationship With Alcohol? (20160428)

comments.commentBody:
Clearly culture plays a big role in one's attitudes towards alcohol and alcohol consumption. There is an attraction to the unattainable that can be considerably blunted by making it accessible in controlled conditions and in small doses. Rather than become a gateway to binge drinking such moderated exposure is more likely to inculcate a healthy attitude towards alcohol and alcohol consumption.

An even bigger factor is the attitudes and behaviors exhibited by one's near and dear friends and family members. As a growing child if you see a parent or a close family friend drink responsibly, you also learn to moderate your own consumption later in life. However, if you see the same adults drink excessively and engage in abusive behaviors, sadly you learn the opposite behaviors.

newswire.abstract: America should identify those responsible for the egregious blunder and do more to compensate the victims’ families.

comments.commentBody:
The report notes that "service members who made the mistakes would not face criminal prosecution because investigators determined that their errors were unintentional."

The same report also notes that "that some service members had flouted the rules of engagement and violated the law of armed conflict."

These two findings run counter to each other. Which is it? I understand that in the tense moments that must accompany any such situation errors are likely. I do not say this lightly, but as a very practical matter. So, if the error was truly unintentional and a human failing (as is the case in many accidents), then I think it is fair to say that these individual must be shielded from public scrutiny. But it is also important that the government pays much more in compensation that the measly amount reported. But, if there is strong reason to believe that "rules were flouted" then it is just as important to pursue prosecuting these individuals.

newswire.abstract: He’s a natural comedian, and his administration knows how to use that.

comments.commentBody:
"But this president has a talent for comedy — an impressive sense of timing and audience."

This statement nails it, cleanly. Obama's ability to tell a joke, with the right pause, right intonation, and follow up with a toothy grin is flawless. He may have missed his calling as a stand-up comedian, but he has more than made that up by being an outstanding President and role model.

How can one forget that moments after ordering the strike on Bin Laden he made his way to crack jokes, without missing a step. Guts and comedy intertwined that evening.

Farewell President Obama! I look forward to hearing you speak and read some of your writings in the future.

asset.assetTitle: Tempest in a Toilet (24bruni)

newswire.title: Tempest in a Toilet
newswire.abstract: If a pee-peeved plutocrat can see the light about transgender people and bathrooms, can’t we all?

comments.commentBody:
Ted Cruz on potty etiquette: “I’m the father of two little girls,” he said. “Here is basic common sense: Grown adult men, strangers, should not be alone in a bathroom with little girls.”

Besides being silly, if not utterly stupid, folks like Ted "use-your-birth-gender-bathroom" Cruz forget that it is impossible to enforce this law. Is he planning to have a cop stationed outside every rest room in America? Are we supposed to carry our birth certificate to a movie so I can show it before using their facilities?

By my rough calculation there are over 250 million rest rooms in America, and hence stationing an officer outside each one will immediately create over 250 million jobs! Take that Obama!

comments.commentBody: Since the names of the original 272 slaves are known, it makes sense to create a memorial and publicly recognize them. Maybe even invite as many of the descendants as can possibly be identified and brought to Georgetown for a ceremonial opening of the memorial. But asking Georgetown to continue paying forever is a bit too much, something this editorial recognizes at the beginning but conveniently side steps towards the end.

multimedia.caption: President Obama with Saudi Foreign Minister Adel Al-Jubeir on Thursday.
President Obama with Saudi Foreign Minister Adel Al-Jubeir on Thursday.
President Obama with Saudi Foreign Minister Adel Al-Jubeir on Thursday.
President Obama with Saudi Foreign Minister Adel Al-Jubeir on Thursday.

newswire.abstract: Despite tensions, the U.S. cannot afford to cut adrift a key regional ally.

comments.commentBody:
The Saudis, our top ally in the ME are also our top enemy. They spread the worst version of Islam (Wahabiism) by setting up madarasas all over the world. From their local neighborhood in the ME all the way across Afghanistan to Indonesia these madarasa have been sprouting. The official Saudi defense is that these are funded by private citizens, but if there is one country where private actions can be easily curbed it is in Saudi Arabia.

Having said all that, it is better to engage the Saudis rather than cut off all relations. But sending arms to support their adventures in Yemen may not be a good idea.

And lastly, more investment in alternate energy sources will be the ultimate way to marginalize the Saudis and their global gas station.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/A New York Primary That Actually Matters (19conversationWEB)
asset.assetTitle: A New York Primary That Actually Matters (19conversationWEB)

taxonomies.name: A New York Primary That Actually Matters (19conversationWEB)

comments.commentBody:
"A friend of mine remarked that Ryan has exactly the two characteristics we most need in a president today — he is amply qualified and has no desire to run."

Apparently Brooks has no ability to make up his own judgment even though he peddles that on the pages of NYT. He needs a friend to tell him about Paul Ryan's virtues, not one but two, ample qualifications but no desire.

All you need to be qualified to run for the office of the POTUS is that you have a pulse. Exhibit A is The Donald. He has a pulse and a lot of hot air spewing out of his mouth. The Donald also began his campaign with little desire to win but soon found himself in a bear hug with power. Just like Ryan did when he declined to be the Speaker but reneged and did accept the position after it got sweetened a bit. I can easily envision Ryan changing his heart and agreeing to run --- "only to save America." But I do not see any chance of his improving his qualifications, which stand at about zero.

newswire.title: Bernie’s Israel Heresy
newswire.abstract: Sanders sets down an important marker for more open American debate of Israeli policies by expressing the consensus view in much of the world.

comments.commentBody:
Cohen notes that the "only one way to support Israel and win elections " is by being uncritical of Israel, ever. It is this expectation of being uncritical that has led to Bibi trying to influence American elections. Anyone else would have rejected the invitation to speak to the American Congress, or at the very least asked for a later date after elections, but Bibi was thrilled to come when invited.

It is time for Americans to see that the tail is wagging the dog.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/A New Map for America (17Khanna)
asset.assetTitle: A New Map for America (17Khanna)

newswire.title: A New Map for America
newswire.abstract: The 50-state model is holding the country back. It needs a new system, built around urban corridors.

comments.commentBody:
Parag Khanna must be applauded for proposing a radical solution to a vexing problem that has arisen from a historical quirk, i.e., how the states were created in the first place over two centuries ago.

However, there is no mention of Joel Garreau's nine-nation map of North America (not just the USA). Almost thiry years back, Professor Garreau saw that there were cultural and political similarities in these nine regions. Professor Khanna has taken it forward and brough it to the twenty-first century. I only wish he had referenced this pioneering work from the past.

For those interested, here are two links to the nine nation proposal:

http://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2014/07/03/where-do-borders-need-to...

https://www.google.com/search?q=garreau+nine+nations&espv=2&biw=...

asset.taxonomy: opinion/‘Trumpo,’ the Unfunny Marx Brother (16cavett)
asset.assetTitle: ‘Trumpo,’ the Unfunny Marx Brother (16cavett)

comments.commentBody:
"These are the disaffected. The disenfranchised. The disdainful."

Income inequality is very high and is recognized as a significant factor affecting millions who are either unemployed or under-employed. It is instructive to recall that all revolutions - French, Russian, or other more minor ones - are preceded by great disparity in society. The top 1%, or royalty in the earlier cases, run the risk of being targeted in violent revolutions unless they are smart enough to help facilitate a drastic reduction in the inequality. It will behoove them to voluntarily take on the burden of additional taxes before matters run out of control.

I don't think we are the point of a violent revolution in America but the seething anger that has propelled Trump and Sanders is real. It is time to remedy this dangerous trend and restore the middle class in order for ALL, including the top 1%, to survive.

newswire.title: How ‘Empowerment’ Became Something for Women to Buy
newswire.abstract: The corporate vision of female strength profits from the same old power dynamics.

comments.commentBody:
"People who talk empowerment are, by definition, already there." It is rarely "defined by the people who actually need it. "

The political equivalent of this would be the American way of trying to impose humanitarian values and democracy in various parts of the world. While laudable as goals, they often reek of paternalistic imposition.

Neither "empowerment" nor "democracy" can be imposed purely from the top down or from the outside-in. It has to be accompanied by a bottom-up, local, and internal movement that comes from those seeking these goals. Absent an inside-out component it is doomed to fail.

comments.commentBody:
"Oftentimes, they don’t want to meet you; they just want proof that they met you."

We are constantly taking videos and photographs on our vacation so we can enjoy them later. What about now?
We are always watching a game or show on TV so we can talk about it tomorrow when we meet a coworker at the water cooler. Why not get into the show or game and enjoy the moment?
We tend to take pictures of our food at restaurants for posting on Instagram. Why not simply savor it at that moment?

Many of us have forgotten to live in the moment, choosing to live for the future and others.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Building a Better Father
asset.assetTitle: Building a Better Father

newswire.title: Building a Better Father
newswire.abstract: When a man loses his reserve, he gains so much more.

comments.commentBody:
Ron Fournier, Paul Ryan, Adam LaRoche and others like them are indeed lucky to be able to spend time with their family, especially kids.

However, they are in the distinct minority, not because men prefer not to spend time with their family, although that is part of the cultural milieu, but because the vast majority do not have the time or energy to do so. We do not have a national policy of providing family leave. Some progressive states and employers provide maternity leave, that too for very short periods, but even fewer provide for parental - read, paternity - leave.

Besides, a large segment of Americans work multiple jobs to make ends meet, robbing them of the valuable time they could have spent with their kids and family. And here we are, even today, debating whether or not to raise the minimum wage to let it get closer to a living wage.

While I appreciate Bruni's column devoting attention to the issue of father's spending time with their kids, I am afraid that absent a national policy in regards parental leave and minimum wage, many father's are doomed to be distant from their kids.

asset.assetTitle: Donald Trump’s Trial-and-Error Campaign  (20160406)

comments.commentBody:
From the time he came gliding down an escalator to launch his bid for the nomination, he has been a showman, nothing more nothing less. And, the corollary to that is that audience size and preferences are crucial for being successful in show business. So it should come as no surprise that he has no knowledge of political issues or guiding principles. He is constantly seeking immediate gratification in terms of the number of people who fawn on him. Not any different from the Kardashians. Who, by the way, are famous for just being famous. Of course the problem is that, unlike the Kardashians who seek fawning platitudes, he is seeking to be the nominee for the office of the President of the United States.

What is the solution? Go to the polls, mobilize voters, and help someone else on the Democratic ticket win. But until then,sit back and enjoy the show.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/What Is This Thing Called Populism? (05conversation)
asset.assetTitle: What Is This Thing Called Populism? (05conversation)

taxonomies.name: What Is This Thing Called Populism? (05conversation)

comments.commentBody:
Poor Gail Collins! I am sure she's thankful it is only once a week.

Here are some of the priceless comments by Arthur Brooks in today's conversation:

1. "And thank God California doesn’t have more than two senators."
Given a chance he'll either throw California out of the union or at least change the number of House members representing California.

2. "a better explanation for Trump’s rise is the simple fact that our economy has created effectively zero percent economic growth for the bottom four-fifths of the population since the Great Recession."
What he really wanted to say was that Obama has not done his job in helping jobs growth. Of course he fails to say who caused the Great Depression, but given that was during the watch of his friend GWB, he'd rather remain mum on that issue.

3. "But I’ve never heard anybody say, “I hate the fact that there are a lot of minorities in the movies today.”
Obviously he has not heard the many artists of different ethnicity - Black, Hispanic, Indian, Chinese - in Hollywood write and speak about how difficult it is for them to get a job playing a person from their own community. I recommend Arthur Brooks to expand the range of his reading before pontificating so wildly.

4. "President Obama sort of tried that in the early years of his administration. It worked poorly."
Even in the face of data that the Obama stimulus helped create jobs and save million f automobile related jobs, Arthur Brooks prefers to keep his head in the sand.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/The Politics of Backlash (05iht-edcohen05)
asset.assetTitle: The Politics of Backlash (05iht-edcohen05)

newswire.title: The Politics of Backlash
newswire.abstract: Another two decades of neo-liberal, reward-the-rich politics will lead to a breakdown in society.

comments.commentBody:
"Equality may demand the restraint of the liberty of those who wish to dominate."

There are many who have written about the notion that one's individual liberty has to be viewed within the ambit of the community's liberty. Nearly a century ago A. G. Gardiner (known by his pen name Alpha of the Plough) wrote:

" You have submitted to a curtailment of private liberty in order that you may enjoy a social order which makes your liberty a reality."

In other words one's individual liberty is heavily dependent on the social contract and absent the social contract the concept of individual liberty loses its meaning.

There is dangerous trend today, particularly in right wing America, wherein the notion of a social contact is decried as useless or false. Recall the umbrage heaped on Elizabeth Warren and President Obama when the made reference to the fact that any one's success is not just the outcome of that person's hard work but a combination of that person's hard work embedded in a civil society that provides infrastructural support.

The current election cycle has, once again, brought out these differences in a stark manner. It is now up to the progressives to continue pushing their message and mobilizing voters. That is the only sure way to keep this governing philosophy alive.

comments.commentBody:
"A woman who chooses to have an abortion is, apparently, not taking responsibility for herself."

And that is why she deserves to be punished. But what about the man who must have been involved to make her pregnant? Obviously the woman seduced him into doing the unimaginable and hence cannot be held responsible. Besides, being a man provides immunity from a lot of things.

Which is why The Donald can say anything, shoot people on the street, ask his supporters to punch opponents in their face, talk ill of Megyn Kelly or Carly Fiorina, and not be held responsible for those attitudes or statements. After all, he's a man.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Dude, Where’s My City? (01egan)
asset.assetTitle: Dude, Where’s My City? (01egan)

comments.commentBody:
First NYC became impossible to live in unless you're willing to live in hole in the wall. Then Boston, and Philadelphia and Washington DC. The flyover parts of America were flown over when San Francisco became too expensive. Just a few days back I read the story of a guy who moved into SF and the only place he could afford was a box in his friend's living room.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2016/03/29/man-moves-...

This is, at least in part, the result of the wide inequality in wealth and income distributions. No one grudges the other person his/her Cadillac, but when I cannot even own and drive a used Yugo, something is terribly wrong. We need a revolution, not the French or Russian types, but one that reverses these unjust and untenable distributions.

I hate to end on a political note, but I have to. You and I have the chance to elect those that will help reverse this trend this November. America, are you up to the task?

newswire.abstract: Donald Trump’s rise shows just how powerless media gatekeepers are.

comments.commentBody:
"For example, academic research shows that rather than deep cuts, Tea Party voters actually favor government programs, as long as they perceive a benefit for themselves."

This column is excellent and should be part of any future analysis on first the rise of the Tea Party and then The Donald. This entire community has no empathy, they can only think of their own welfare. Anything and everything is viewed through the lens of "what's in it for me." They are anti-government until they or one of their own loses a job. And then unemployment insurance and SNAP become important. If "someone else" was unemployed it was only because s/he was lazy. Cliven Bundy and his ilk are a living example of this warped philosophy. He has his cattle graze on federal land but will not pay for it.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/The Republican Gun-Free Zone (31collins)
asset.assetTitle: The Republican Gun-Free Zone (31collins)

newswire.title: The Republican Gun-Free Zone
newswire.abstract: If you want to be safe from being shot by a well-armed Donald Trump or Ted Cruz, go to the G.O.P.’s convention.

comments.commentBody:
After the massacre in Paris, The Donald has famously said, "“You know what? If I’m in that room and let’s say we have two or five or 40 people with guns, we’re going to do a lot better because there’s going to be a shootout."

This reminded me of a guy who was worried that there might be a bomb on the flight he would be taking. He decided to carry a bomb himself under the logic that the odds of a flight having two people carrying bombs was infinitesimally smaller than that of one person carrying one bomb.

Welcome to the world of The Donald and the Second Amendment aficionados.

Notwithstanding this upside down logic, they are smart enough to recognize that they do not want guns at places where there is a public debate, such as at the Republican National Convention. Unfortunately the secret service took a public stand of not allowing guns at this convention and provided cover for these chicken-hawk politicians. I'd have loved to hear Ted I-eat-my-bacon-smoked-on-a-barrel Cruz wax eloquent about how safe he feels with a thousand people carrying guns at the convention. This ought to show the world the double standards applied by these chicken-hawks. They are for guns all over the place, anywhere and anytime, but not where they may be endangered.

Wake up America! Smell the coffee! Vote these bums out! That power is in our hands.

org_facet: Blue Cross and Blue Shield Assn
newswire.abstract: To the Obama administration, the new data is seen as evidence that there has been pent-up demand for the policy signed into law by the president.

comments.commentBody:
It is hardly surprising that the newly insured "were sicker, used more medical care and had higher medical costs than those who already had coverage." The reason they did not buy healthcare, in large part, was because they could either not afford it or were shut out by pre-existing conditions. But since Obamacare was enacted into law they can now enter the marketplace.
I fully understand that my annual cost may have gone up as a result of that and may continue to go up even further. But I view that as my civic duty to help others so that everyone can gain access to healthcare. Besides, those who were earlier shut out of the healthcare market would have gone to emergency care raising our collective cost in a different manner. I'd like to know if that has decreased. And if so, the increased cost has to be seen as an offset as a decrease in the cost of providing emergency care.

asset.assetTitle: Trump's New World Disorder (29iht-edcohen29)

newswire.title: Trump's New World Disorder
newswire.abstract: Trump thinks America is being ripped off and NATO is obsolete, but war in Estonia or the East China Sea could be the biggest rip-off of all.

comments.commentBody:
As the saying goes, "Power corrupts, absolute power absolutely corrupts." Trump knows very little and is not nuanced. He will centralize as much power as he can, all in the name of making America strong and respected again. And just like his business dealings there will be murky and shady aspects to his administration. And we will be in a far worse place four years into his presidency. If you thought that GWB was bad, just imagine how much worse we'll be with Trump at the helm. He is piqued that Germany is not toeing his line, just bomb them and they'll respect us. He does not like Iran, why not just send a couple of the many nukes we have. After all they're rotting in a silo somewhere.
Be afraid, be very afraid.

newswire.abstract: The party establishment abandoned its most faithful voters, blue-collar workers who faced economic pain while donors, lawmakers and lobbyists prospered.

comments.commentBody:
Remember the book "What's the matter with Kansdas?" from about a decade ago? One of the arguments presented in that book was that social conservatives voted for Republicans, even though they are voting against their economic interests just because their social agenda was aligned with the party's. However, the social changes over the past decade have essentially run against them and so right now all that these people have to focus on is their economic welfare. And finally they realized that the Republicans did not represent their interests but that of those in the top tier. Their natural tendency would have been to swing to the Democratic party but instead they saw Trump peddling his wares. And even though he was selling false promises that were total nonsense, these folks supported him.
And that is how Trump is where he is. Until these people realize that he is a chimera, they'll support him. They do not realize as yet that their true benefactor is Bernie Sanders. And the reason is because they do not understand or like the word socialism. They do not realize we already have a social safety net and are in a social democracy.
So the fog in Kansas has not yet fully cleared. That may take another four years or so.

newswire.abstract: Even though Russia has begun withdrawing from Syria, its aerial bombing campaign has bolstered President Bashar al-Assad’s confidence and ambitions.

comments.commentBody: And for all those who have urged Obama to rush into Syria, I hope you see how smart it was to wait this out. You'll say that a number of Syrian refugees are involved and represents a huge human tragedy. Yes, I agree. But that human tragedy would not have been averted or slowed down with greater American involvement. Chances are it would have become another quagmire, just like Iraq, costing America far more in terms of in lives and money. So, think about that when you recommend American involvement all over the world. Sometimes sitting out and standing still is a good strategy.
